utterances: Dana Priest of the Washington Post.
Thanks so much for speaking with us.
Thank you, Andrea.
The White House is calling for Pakistan to get back on its path to democracy after Pakistan's president, Pervez Musharraf, suspended the country's constitution over the weekend.
News analyst Daniel Schorr says Pakistan is only the latest example of a flawed philosophy.
President Bush's most cherished preset that spreading democracy spreads stability is going down in flames in the Middle East.
Pakistan's President Musharraf, beset and beleaguered by Islamic extremists, has declared an emergency.
Those tokens of democracy, the parliament and the Supreme Court, are under siege.
Thousands of critics of his authoritarian rule have been arrested without warrants or charges and that core of democracy, the election, may be postponed to the indefinite future.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice says that the $150 million a month in American aid is being reviewed.
But that is a charade.
Having enlisted Musharraf in the war on terror, the Bush administration has no other viable options.
There are other setbacks on the democracy's stability front in the Middle East.
Turkey, our model of democracy, is threatening armed incursion into northern Iraq to route out the Kurdish guerillas seeking an independent Kurdistan.
That could destabilize the elected government of Iraq.
In Lebanon, another one's promising democracy, running for president is almost tantamount to running for assassination by serious henchmen.
And in the Israel- Palestinian areas, Secretary Rice is fighting an uphill battle to stitch together a peace conference in Annapolis later this month or may be next.
A self-selected international crisis group, including Zbigniew Brzezinski, Lee Hamilton and Brent Scowcroft, has warned the failure of this peace effort risks devastating consequences.
What seems clear is that the Annapolis conference, if it happens, will be the start of a process not its culmination.
That both the Israeli and Palestinian authorities result from democratic elections does not assure a successful outcome.
We are a long way from Cold War days when hawkish ambassador Jeane Kirkpatrick was willing to deal with moderately repressive autocratic governance as long as they were anti-communists.
Now, it may be that the Bush administration will deal with repressive regimes as long as they are anti-terrorists.
This is Daniel Schorr.
The population of Iowa, according to the latest figures, is 2,982,085.
But that number does not take into account all the presidential candidates, their staffs, and the reporters covering them who have all descended upon the state this holiday week.
Now, the skeptics may say, just move the club to a new space.
What's the big deal?
There are a number of moving pieces that are possible.
We haven't made any decisions in any way, shape, or form as far as I know, about any transfers.
No decisions about the transfers, but a lot of groundwork has been laid.
As envisioned now, the swap would include the Taliban's former ministers of defense, interior and intelligence, all of whom have been in Guantanamo for the past decade.
These are really important people and I think it's more than symbolic.
Again, U.N.'s Richard Barrett.
They'd be joined by their families and so on.
There would be an office there.
They'd be in communication with their Taliban friends.
And then you could argue that actually they would give a boost to the movement.
Whether it was a boost towards peace or whether it's a boost towards more war, well, that would remain to be seen.
The hope is that the prisoner release would lead to talks between the U.S.
and Taliban and would eventually pave the way for the one thing that is required for peace in Afghanistan: formal reconciliation talks between the Taliban and the Afghan government.
U.S.
officials say they aren't sure why the Taliban has had this sudden change of heart.
They say the Taliban may now have a better idea of what the future of their country looks like and they want to be a part of it.
Barrett says the prisoner swap and what follows won't be easy because both sides have a careful calculus to make.
And of course it's that casting an agreement as victory, or at least not defeat, which is really important to both sides.
And even if both can eventually declare victory, it's unclear how trading five Taliban leaders for America's only known prisoner of war will be received.
Dina Temple-Raston, NPR News.
From NPR News this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Audie Cornish.
For several weeks now, two unmanned spy planes have been flying over the Atlantic on an unusual mission.
They're gathering intelligence on tropical storms and hurricanes for NASA.
Well, NPR's Jon Hamilton went on his own mission to find out what scientists are learning from those drones.
He visited NASA's flight facility on Wallops Island, Virginia.
On a runway at Wallops a graceful snow white aircraft is gathering speed for takeoff.
It's destination?
A tropical storm named Gabrielle.
The Global Hawk has a Rolls Royce engine, the wingspan of a 737 and no pilot onboard.
The pilots are sitting in front of computer screens in a nearby building.
Chris Naftel is NASA's Global Hawk project manager.
Manned aircraft are limited by pilot endurance and that's typically eight to ten hours, at the most.
Naftel says the drones can fly for more than 24 hours at a stretch.
That gives us that ability to extend our time when we're looking at these science phenomena over a weather system.
The Global Hawks also can fly miles higher than commercial aircraft and reach storms that would be much too far away for conventional planes.
Naftel says that from the drone's usual home in California...
We could take off, fly to New York and back, and do that again and back on one tank of fuel.
So, incredible range.
We can get to the coast of Africa and then come back to here at Wallops.
Scientists took advantage of that range last year while studying an unusual hurricane named Nadine, which spent weeks meandering around the far reaches of the Northeast Atlantic.
Scott Braun is the scientist in charge of NASA's five-year Hurricane and Severe Storm Sentinel Mission.
He says Nadine was beyond the range of most U.S.
aircraft but the Global Hawks were able to send back a huge amount of data as Nadine weakened to a tropical storm, then surprisingly began to regain hurricane strength.
Nadine, at that point, was over fairly cold water and the winds were such that the storm should've been getting sheared apart and yet, it survived.
So what was scientifically interesting about Nadine was its resilience despite very adverse surrounding conditions.
Data from the Global Hawks turned up one possible explanation.
Even though Nadine had traveled far north, it retained a mass of warm air at its core.
That gave it the ability to re-strengthen quickly when conditions became more favorable.
This year, scientists are using the drones to study something called the Saharan Air Layer, a mass of hot dry and dusty air that comes off the Sahara every few days.
Braun says the Saharan Air Layer interacts with waves of low pressure air that can turn into hurricanes as they head across the Atlantic.
Some have argued that the Saharan Air Layer is actually favorable for the growth of those waves and ultimately, for the development of tropical cyclones because it provides an energy source.
Hot air, which is good for a hurricane; but the air is also dry, which is bad.
So weather scientists think the Saharan Air Layer can actually kill a baby hurricane.
The debate has been hard to settle because it involves weather thousands of miles from the U.S.
Braun says having the Global Hawks should help with that problem.
It allows us to get the systems at that very early stage when the Saharan Air Layer is most interacting with storms.
So we're getting to storms much earlier in their lifecycle than we would if we had to wait for them to get out to the Western Atlantic.
Braun says the Global Hawks have spent much of the past couple of weeks flying over and around tropical storm Gabrielle as it churned up the east coast.
He says detailed information about Gabrielle may eventually help scientists understand why some tropical storms quickly intensify into hurricanes while others don't.
And the National Hurricane Center has already used data from the Global Hawks to help make forecasts about Gabrielle.
Gary Wick of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says that shows how drones could play an important role in weather forecasting.
I really see the Global Hawk as bridging the gap between aircrafts and satellites.

That you're now able to fly at altitudes, get coverage comparable to what you would with a satellite but really dwell over that system for an extended period of time, get some of those detailed measurements.
At a cost.
Global Hawks go for more than $100 million each, not counting research and development.
Jon Hamilton, NPR News.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Yeah, I'm going to guess it was Phil McConkey, played for the Giants.

With some six months to go before Iowa holds its first in the nation presidential caucuses, we thought we'd check in with two NPR correspondents who are in the state following candidates and talking to voters.
NPR's David Greene is with the Hillary Clinton campaign in Iowa City, and Ina Jaffe is covering Mitt Romney and she joins us from between campaign stops in Anita, Iowa.
Welcome to both of you.
Hi, Robert.
Hello, Robert.
David, the big news with the Clinton campaign this week is that Senator Clinton is campaigning in Iowa with a very famous political figure who has a very familiar last name.
There's always the risk of Bill Clinton outshining his wife on the campaign trail.
That's right.
What's the impression in watching the two.
That was the big question for the Hillary Clinton campaign was if and when she was going to have her husband tag along and we got the answer.
He's out here with her for three days this week, stopping in one town after another.
And you're right.
There was some risk.
I mean, Mr. Clinton is still a rock star among Democrats, and the campaign has been really careful.
It seems like they have, on one hand, tried to generate a lot of attention about this.
They even have a Hill Cam, a camera set up to give voters a look at some of their unscripted moments.
But when they actually get on the stage at these events, Bill Clinton keeps his remarks very brief.
He says he's focusing on his wife, and he doesn't speak that long and, which, of course, he wasn't famous for when he was president.
Ina, the former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney, a Republican aspirant, is holding one of his Ask Mitt Anything events.
What are those like?
Well, there are usually about 50, 60, 70 people there and they do ask him just about anything.
The questions have been far ranging from health care to social security, Iran, Iraq, abortion, Israel and Palestine.
The issue that seems to really get people the most anxious and sometimes even angry is illegal immigration.
